captions.text:
From the company who has the rights to Godzilla,
King Kong, and Pacific Rim --

so please, please, do a crossover where they
all fight each other & stuff --

Comes the best American Godzilla movie ever
made...

Prepare for a movie that was sold as a face
off between Walter White and Godzilla
Yet barely contains any Bryan Cranston

Seriously, there's less than 20 minutes
of him. We counted.
Get ready for the tease of the summer,

bringing you the king of monsters like you've
never seen him before:
Shot from really long distances on television

spend 80% of the runtime with two monsters
that no one has ever heard of:
And this moth who is totally not Mothra.

Then watch as they fight against all odds
to find a safe place to pork.

Instead of watching the title character kick
ass,

spend hours of screen-time with Kick Ass and
the rest of his boring family.

There's his dad, whose wig is almost as
bad as his Japanese.

Kick Ass' wife, an emergency room nurse
who reacts to a crisis by abandoning her patients
and pawning off her only child on a coworker.

He's a professional bomb disposal expert
who never defuses any bombs,
a magnet for every single giant monster,

an a-hole who keeps volunteering for dangerous
missions instead of coming home to his wife

"If you don't walk out, you don't come back
at all."

and a hero who spends more time and effort
saving this random boy he met on a train than
he does trying to save his own family.

"I'm gonna be at the house by sunrise. Then
I'm gonna get you and Sam out."
Tell them to run, you idiot!
In a nod to the series' Japanese roots,

who's only in the movie to dramatically
say one name:

Man, if that's what his breath is like, I'd
hate to see his farts.

comments.text:
Am I the only one who was more scared with the original black and white 
one?  That one had plenty of suspense, and Godzilla actually being 
terrifying.  You know what they say, you can't beat the classics.  I think 
this movie would have been great if Bryan Cranston was the main character 
the whole time.  He actually had a connection to Godzilla with his wife 
dying.  That made it interesting. But no.... We get to see his boring son 
for most of the movie.  Cranston would have saved it.  I think two 
Godzillas fighting over each other would have been a lot better than two 
monsters trying to have sex.  

Honest trailers has it right.﻿

comments.author: I'm Gandalf and Magneto deal with it

comments.text:
I loved this version of Godzilla. I believed Gareth Evans true intention of 
this movie was to put you in a world where a monster existed, which I 
actually felt like I did and not to follow the actors purpose for the 
movie. Let's face it, if you were in a city where two monsters fought, 
wouldn't you want to find shelter and safety instead of risking your life 
watching them fight (tbh, I'm half and half on this)? It's like watching a 
natural disaster occur. It looks fucking awesome through media, but 
experiencing it is the craziest and scariest thing ever that will make you 
not want to experience it again. You may say Godzilla didn't get enough 
screen time and I don't care for watching lots of people, but it's just 
what you will experience in a world such as this: struggling with FEMA, 
worried about deployed family members, scared shitless being in the 
military fighting these fucking things, and executing a HALO jump like the 
SEALS did in the movie. That's my opinion on this movie, and if you agreed 
that's cool. If you didnt, it won't affect me that much.﻿

comments.text:
Fun Fact: Godzilla was actually gonna be Gorrila. In the 1950s godzilla had 
very small bad spikes and was even called "Gojira" It was supposed to be 
furry giant similar to King Kong but more like Terrorising the City. After 
Americans thought it was a lizard the Godzilla creators made it more Lizard 
like. So if you hate this movie.....
..remember that it couldve been a King Kong Knockoff thats even worse﻿
